utterances: Barmak Nassirian is with the American Association of College Registrars and Admissions Officers.
He says this lobbying campaign is targeted at the majority party in the Congress.
This is an attempt to peel off as many Democrats as possible, to throw sand in the machinery.
The lobbying has resonated with two Democrats at least.
Senator Mary Landrieu of Louisiana wrote the Senate's majority leader and gave exactly the message laid out in the Sallie Mae talking point.
Landrieu warned of the possibility of, quote, ""a very harmful impact"" on students and historically black colleges and universities in Louisiana.
Her colleague in the House, Lincoln Davis of Tennessee, warned of similar harms to lower income students if private student lenders have to take cuts.
Libby Lewis, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Jennifer Ludden.
The deadline has passed.
The Israeli government now deems it illegal for civilians to be in the Gaza Strip.
Tomorrow Israeli soldiers will start knocking on settlers' doors with evacuation orders.
Wednesday they'll use force to evict any settlers who remain.
Israeli seized Gaza in the 1967 war.
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon pushed through the pullout over heated domestic opposition.
Working with the Israeli army, the Palestinian Authority is deploying some 7,500 security officers around the Gaza settlements.
They're to prevent militant attacks on the departing Israelis and any looting of the empty settlements.
Today several thousand settlers held a prayer vigil at the Jewish cemetery in Gaza.
NPR's Linda Gradstein was there.
(Soundbite of prayer vigil)
(Singing in Hebrew)
On the Jewish calendar, today was the day of fasting and mourning for the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem.
In the Jewish settlements in Gaza, it also became a day of mourning for homes and lives here.
It is a tradition to visit cemeteries on this holy day, and more than 2,000 settlers jammed the small cemetery in Neveh Dekalim, the largest Jewish settlement.
His voice breaking, Rabbi Yosef Elnikaveh, the rabbi of Neveh Dekalim, beseeched the souls of the dead to pray for the cancellation of the Gaza withdrawal.
(Through Translator) Go to our holy patriarches and matriarches and say this.
We want to stay here.
Tell them you don't want anyone touching your grave.
May this prayer, the prayer of bereaved parents, of widows, of orphans, to be heard.
The crowd then sang biblical songs for more than an hour.
Every time the rabbi tried to end the ceremony, they kept singing.
Many of them cried and hugged each other.
Although publicly many of these settlers say they believe a miracle will happen and the Gaza withdrawal will be canceled, the ceremony felt like a farewell.
At the back of the cemetery, Don Davidovich(ph) has draped an Israeli flag over his daughter Ahovah's(ph) grave.
She was killed in a drive-by shooting by Palestinians almost three years ago at age 30, leaving behind two young children.
Like all of the other graves here, it will have to be moved, a notion that horrifies Davidovich.
(Through Translator) The strongest connection to the land of Israel is being buried here.
Instead of walking on top of the ground, the dead person is surrounded by all the land, and everything we took from the land goes back to it.
A nation that digs up graves is not a nation.
A few miles away, in his house in the settlement of Gadid, Yarhiem Shar Avi(ph) is packing up to move.
Shar Avi, a farmer, was one of the founders of the settlement 23 years ago, and he and his wife raised their five children here.
After much vacillation, they've decided to accept the government compensation and move to a new town the government is building inside Israel.
But he says he won't leave until the very last minute.
(Foreign language spoken)
`I feel like they didn't treat us well,' he said.
`Nobody from the government came here and explained what was happening.
We feel like they're just humiliating us.'
Unlike Shar Avi, some settlers say they will not go quietly.
On the walls of the settlement of Neveh Dekalim are posters explaining how to make things tough for the soldiers.
There are instructions on how to disable the engines of the buses that will come to take the settlers out.
And if that doesn't work, the posters say, rocking the bus back and forth might tip it over.
Protesters plan to flood the Israeli side of the border and stop the soldiers from entering Gaza.
Along with the almost 9,000 Jewish residents in Gaza, an estimated 5,000 other Israelis have infiltrated into Gaza in the past few weeks.
Military officials say that while the army realizes it will be painful for settlers to leave their homes, it will use force if necessary to remove them.
Linda Gradstein, NPR News, Gadid settlement in Gaza.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Celeste Headlee in Washington.
Neal Conan is away.
Hillary returns to work, Boehner returns to the dais, Panetta returns to the farm.
It's Wednesday and time for a...
Dealing with a different set of nuts...
Edition of the Political Junkie.
The legislation concerning Carter is the federal Combat Meth Act.
In many ways, it mirrors Iowa's law, putting drugs containing pseudoephedrine behind the counter and requiring buyers to show ID and sign a log.
What Carter and law enforcement officials in some other states don't like is a provision in the law that would pre-empt state anti-meth laws.
Missouri Republican Senator Jim Talent is one of the bill's main sponsors.

He says one of the benefits of a federal anti-meth law is that it would establish a single national standard for pseudoephedrine sales that, he argues, would benefit both law enforcement and consumers.
The single standard permits the law enforcement to, you know, enforce the laws as part of a seamless web because everybody's going to be reporting and accounting the same way.
And we're also hopeful that it will hold down unnecessary costs.
You know, it's going to be a little harder for consumers to get these cold medicines, and, you know, we don't want to make it more costly for them at the same time.
Because of the new state laws, Pfizer and other drug companies are now beginning to sell versions of their decongestants that don't contain pseudoephedrine and which can't be used to make meth.
But at the same time drug companies and retailers are actively lobbying in Washington for a federal law that would pre-empt the growing number of state anti-meth measures.
John Motley is with the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group that represents Wal-Mart and some 1,300 retailers and wholesalers.
If you have 50 different state standards and, within those states, literally hundreds of local standards, it's much more difficult for them and for their employees to understand what they have to do.
In Iowa, Oklahoma and other states, law enforcement officials are taking their concerns about the Combat Meth Act to their representatives in Congress.
Because it's still in committee, it's not clear exactly what the final bill will contain.

But the head of Iowa's Office of Drug Control, Marvin Van Haaften, says he's concerned about provisions that he says would actually weaken Iowa's tough law, including one allowing drugs containing pseudoephedrine to be sold by convenience stores in areas where there are no pharmacies.
I know the intense lobbying efforts we faced here.
I'm sure at the federal level it is that times 10 or perhaps even more.
It worries me because whatever the federal law is, if it pre-empts the state law, that's what we have to live with.

At bottom, Van Haaften says, there's a suspicion among state law enforcement officials that drug companies and retailers who fought and lost when anti-meth laws were being debated in state capitals are now just taking the battle to Washington.
Greg Allen, NPR News.
This spring, tomato pickers in Immokalee, Florida, reached an unprecedented agreement with one of the world's biggest fast-food companies.
Yum!
Brands, which owns Taco Bell and other chains, agreed that Taco Bell will only buy tomatoes in Immokalee from growers who pay their pickers almost double the going wages and treat them with respect.
This followed a four-year boycott of Taco Bell.
NPR's Daniel Zwerdling told us that story yesterday.
Today, he reports on how the Immokalee farm workers are making sure the promises on paper come to life in the fields.
The farm workers' leaders say if this new agreement with Yum!
Brands is going to work, then every tomato picker around Immokalee has to understand exactly what they've won.
So the Coalition of Immokalee Workers is spreading the word.
(Soundbite of radio broadcast)
Unidentified Man #1: (Spanish spoken)
Turn on your radio any afternoon in this sandy farm town, go to 107.9 and you'll hear Radio la Tuya, Your Radio.
The Coalition of Immokalee Workers set up this tiny radio station in the corner of an old storeroom.
One minute, the deejay is playing ranchero music...
(Soundbite of music)
...next, he's calling farm workers to a big meeting to help make the Taco Bell agreement work.
(Soundbite of radio broadcast)
Unidentified Man #2: (Spanish spoken)
This deejay is Lucas Benitez.
He was the main organizers of the Taco Bell boycott.
He's saying, `There's an important meeting coming up Wednesday night at the coalition office near Main Street.
We have changed the time to 7:30 so all of you can come.'
(Soundbite of radio broadcast)
Unidentified Man #2: (Spanish spoken)
Of course, farm workers don't always hear the program.
(Soundbite of knocking)
So an organizer named Gerardo Chavez goes to a farmer worker housing project later the same night.
Buenas noches.
(In unison) Buenas noches.
Como esta?
He goes door to door down the rows of little white cabins near a grove of palm trees...
(Spanish spoken)
...and he asks farm workers to Wednesday's meeting in person.
